title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 preamble is amended by acknowledging the Lumbee Indians as descendants of coastal North Carolina tribes, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Tribe should now receive full Federal recognition. The Lumbee Indians are recognized as descendants of coastal North Carolina tribes and should now receive full Federal recognition with benefits and privileges. The Lumbee Indians are recognized as descendants of coastal North Carolina tribes and should now receive full Federal recognition with benefits and privileges, as stated in SEC. 3. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive benefits and services provided to federally recognized tribes. Indians in certain counties can petition for tribal acknowledgement. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be living near an Indian tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, residing in specific counties, is granted Federal recognition to receive tribal benefits and services. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will collaborate with the tribe to determine needs and budget for eligible services. The tribal roll defines the service population, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted Federal recognition for tribal benefits and services. The tribe's constitution must be verified for compliance with membership criteria. Fee lands in Robeson County will be treated as trust acquisitions. North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on tribal lands. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers from the state. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina may transfer jurisdiction to the United States after consulting with the Attorney General. The transfer cannot take effect until 2 years after the agreement. This subsection does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. Appropriations are authorized for implementing this Act.
